verses.text: The one who does this will not become rich; one who despises small things will fail little by little.
verses.comment: Sirach warns that neglecting small opportunities or responsibilities undermines one's prosperity; diligence in minor matters is a hallmark of biblical wisdom (cf. Luke 16:10).

verses.text: Wine and women lead the wise astray, and he who keeps company with prostitutes will lose all sense.
verses.comment: This verse warns against the dangers of intemperance and immoral living, which can destroy wisdom and judgment. The biblical tradition consistently calls God's people to purity and self-control.

verses.text: Decay and worms will take possession of him, and the reckless person will be snatched away.
verses.comment: The imagery of 'decay and worms' is a traditional reminder of mortality and judgment for the reckless, echoing themes found in Job 17:14 and Isaiah 14:11.

verses.text: He who trusts too quickly is lacking in understanding, and he who sins offends his own soul.
verses.comment: Discretion and cautious judgment—especially in trusting others—are necessary virtues. This aligns with the repeated call in Wisdom Literature to seek the Spirit’s guidance in all relationships.

verses.text: One who rejoices in wickedness will be condemned.
verses.comment: Rejoicing in evil reveals a hardened heart, and such delight leads to condemnation, consistent with Proverbs 17:5 and Romans 1:32.

verses.text: But one who hates gossip has less evil.
verses.comment: Avoiding gossip promotes personal righteousness and minimizes sin, reflecting the wisdom of Proverbs 16:28 and James 3:5-8 regarding the dangers of the tongue.

verses.text: Do not tell others what you have heard, and you will not be harmed.
verses.comment: Maintaining confidentiality keeps peace between brothers. This is an early witness to the call for charity and forbearance in community.

verses.text: Whether it is about a friend or a foe, do not speak of it; unless it is a sin for you to be silent, do not reveal it.
verses.comment: This verse advises prudence about when (or if) to speak. There are times when silence is not only prudent, but righteous.

verses.text: For someone has heard you and watched you, and when the time comes he will hate you.
verses.comment: Our words can return to harm us if spoken without caution. The wisdom tradition warns of consequences for speaking loosely.

verses.text: Have you heard a word? Let it die with you. Be assured, it will not make you burst.
verses.comment: It is better to control one’s tongue than to cause harm by sharing needlessly. Mastery over speech is an ancient spiritual discipline.

verses.text: A fool will suffer labor pains to speak out what he knows, like a woman in labor with a child.
verses.comment: The analogy shows a fool's compulsion to share secrets. The wise are marked by self-restraint, while the fool cannot keep his peace.

verses.text: Like an arrow lodged in the flesh of the thigh, so is a word inside a fool.
verses.comment: Ill-spoken words fester and bring harm to all. This passage reminds us of the power our words can carry.

verses.text: Question your friend if he has done you wrong, and if he is guilty, rebuke him so he may not do it again.
verses.comment: Direct confrontation with charity and justice heals relationships. Christ repeats this command for community life in the gospels.

verses.text: If someone has spoken unkindly of you, let it be between you and him alone, unless he repeats it.
verses.comment: Confronting offenses privately follows the biblical pattern for resolving disputes in love and seeking reconciliation first in private.

verses.text: If he has done it, that he may not do it to you again; but if he has not done it, do not say a word.
verses.comment: Restoration is the goal, not revenge. The wisdom here prepares for the larger Christian call to mercy and reconciliation.

verses.text: A person may make a slip without intending it. Who has not sinned with his tongue?
verses.comment: This verse acknowledges human frailty in speech and calls for compassion, paralleling James 3:2: 'We all stumble in many ways,' highlighting the universality of such failings.

verses.text: Question your neighbor before you threaten him; and let the law of the Most High take its course.
verses.comment: Sirach urges measured judgment and reliance on divine law before resorting to threats, promoting reconciliation and justice (see Matthew 7:1-2).

verses.text: A wise person is patient, but a fool is quick to speak and is counted worthy of nothing.
verses.comment: Patience and listening are the marks of wisdom, which are echoed in James’ call to be 'slow to speak, slow to anger' (James 1:19).

verses.text: The knowledge of the wise will increase like the rising tide, and their counsel will endure like a river.
verses.comment: Wisdom is a living stream that grows and brings life. This points forward to Christ, who is the true Wisdom and Living Water for the people of God.
verses.sectionHeader: True Wisdom and the Fear of the Lord

verses.text: The whole of wisdom is fear of the Lord, and in all wisdom there is the fulfillment of the law.
verses.comment: True wisdom is rooted in the fear of the Lord and is inseparable from obedience to His law, a central theme in Proverbs (1:7; 9:10) and Deuteronomy 10:12.

verses.text: The fear of the Lord is all wisdom, and all wisdom is in keeping with the law.
verses.comment: Wisdom and obedience to God’s law are inseparable. This principle underlies Jesus’ teaching in the Sermon on the Mount concerning the fulfillment of the law.

verses.text: The knowledge of wickedness is not wisdom, nor is there prudence in the counsel of sinners.
verses.comment: Knowledge divorced from godliness is false wisdom; corrupt counsel, even if clever, is condemned, as also stressed in James 3:13-15.

verses.text: There is a cleverness that is detestable, and there is a fool who merely lacks wisdom.
verses.comment: There is 'cleverness' (cunning) that is morally repugnant, underscoring the difference between skill and righteousness—wisdom is more than mere intelligence (cf. 1 Corinthians 3:19).

verses.text: Better are the God-fearing who lack understanding than the highly intelligent who transgress the law.
verses.comment: God-fearing simplicity is superior to intellectual brilliance without obedience, echoing Jesus' preference for humble servants (cf. 1 Corinthians 1:26-29).

verses.text: There is a cleverness that is exact but unjust, and there are people who abuse favors to gain a verdict.
verses.comment: Skillful manipulation or exploitation of generosity for unjust ends is critiqued, aligning with Hebrew legal traditions that champion justice (Exodus 23:8).

verses.text: There is the villain bowed down in mourning, but inwardly he is full of deceit.
verses.comment: Outward expressions of sorrow can disguise inward deceit, cautioning against hypocrisy reminiscent of warnings in Matthew 6:16-18.

verses.text: He hides his face and pretends not to hear, but when no one notices, he will take advantage of you.
verses.comment: Feigned ignorance or inattentiveness can mask intentions to take advantage, highlighting the importance of discernment in relational dealings.

verses.text: Even if lack of strength keeps him from sinning, he will nevertheless do evil when he finds the opportunity.
verses.comment: This verse reveals that the lack of opportunity—not virtue—may prevent wrongdoing, echoing Jesus' teaching that intent matters as much as action (Matthew 5:28).

verses.text: A person is known by his appearance, and a sensible person is known when first met, face to face.
verses.comment: A person's appearance and demeanor often reveal character, reflecting the biblical emphasis on wisdom being evident in conduct (Proverbs 20:11; Matthew 7:16-20).

verses.text: A person's dress, the way he laughs, and the way he walks all proclaim what he is.
verses.comment: Outward behavior often manifests inner disposition, but as the Lord told Samuel, man looks at outward appearance, but God sees the heart. Virtue should transform both our hearts and our lives outwardly.

sections.title: True Wisdom and the Fear of the Lord
